natural problem:
The chart below gives the air distance in miles between selected world cities. If two different cities from the chart are chosen at random, what is the probability that the distance between them is less than $7000$ miles? Express your answer as a common fraction.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
& Bangkok & Cape Town & Honolulu & London \\ \hline
Bangkok & & 6300 & 6609 & 5944 \\ \hline
Cape Town & 6300 & & 11,535 & 5989 \\ \hline
Honolulu & 6609 & 11,535 & & 7240 \\ \hline
London & 5944 & 5989 & 7240 & \\ \hline
\end{tabular}
natural solution: Although there are 12 entries on the table, there are only 6 different ``pairs'' of cities. Of the 6 pairs, 4 of them are less than 7,000 miles apart, yielding a $\boxed{\frac{2}{3}}$ probability that you select a pair less than 7,000 miles apart.

a_0.formal problem:
theorem
fixes d :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "d 1 2 = 6300"
and h1 : "d 1 3 = 6609"
and h2 : "d 1 4 = 5944"
and h3 : "d 2 1 = 6300"
and h4 : "d 2 3 = 11535"
and h5 : "d 2 4 = 5989"
and h6 : "d 3 1 = 6609"
and h7 : "d 3 2 = 11535"
and h8 : "d 3 4 = 7240"
and h9 : "d 4 1 = 5944"
and h10 : "d 4 2 = 5989"
and h11 : "d 4 3 = 7240"
and h12 : "count { (i, j). i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4} \<and> j \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4} \<and> i \<noteq> j \<and> d i j < 7000} = 4"
and h13 : "count { (i, j). i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4} \<and> j \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4} \<and> i \<noteq> j} = 6"
shows  "Fraction 2 3"
a_0.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The chart below gives the air distance in miles between selected world cities. If two different cities from the chart are chosen at random, what is the probability that the distance between them is less than $7000$ miles? Express your answer as a common fraction.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
& Bangkok & Cape Town & Honolulu & London \\ \hline
Bangkok & & 6300 & 6609 & 5944 \\ \hline
Cape Town & 6300 & & 11,535 & 5989 \\ \hline
Honolulu & 6609 & 11,535 & & 7240 \\ \hline
London & 5944 & 5989 & 7240 & \\ \hline
\end{tabular} The final Answer is \frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 Although there are 12 entries on the table, there are only 6 different ``pairs'' of cities. Of the 6 pairs, 4 of them are less than 7,000 miles apart, yielding a $\boxed{\frac{2}{3}}$ probability that you select a pair less than 7,000 miles apart.
 *)

theorem
fixes d :: "int \<Rightarrow> int \<Rightarrow> int"
assumes h0 : "d 1 2 = 6300"
and h1 : "d 1 3 = 6609"
and h2 : "d 1 4 = 5944"
and h3 : "d 2 1 = 6300"
and h4 : "d 2 3 = 11535"
and h5 : "d 2 4 = 5989"
and h6 : "d 3 1 = 6609"
and h7 : "d 3 2 = 11535"
and h8 : "d 3 4 = 7240"
and h9 : "d 4 1 = 5944"
and h10 : "d 4 2 = 5989"
and h11 : "d 4 3 = 7240"
and h12 : "count { (i, j). i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4} \<and> j \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4} \<and> i \<noteq> j \<and> d i j < 7000} = 4"
and h13 : "count { (i, j). i \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4} \<and> j \<in> {1, 2, 3, 4} \<and> i \<noteq> j} = 6"
shows  "Fraction 2 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_0.informal problem:
There are 4 locations. The distances between them are as follows:
- Distance between location 1 and 2 is 6300.
- Distance between location 1 and 3 is 6609.
- Distance between location 1 and 4 is 5944.
- Distance between location 2 and 1 is 6300.
- Distance between location 2 and 3 is 11535.
- Distance between location 2 and 4 is 5989.
- Distance between location 3 and 1 is 6609.
- Distance between location 3 and 2 is 11535.
- Distance between location 3 and 4 is 7240.
- Distance between location 4 and 1 is 5944.
- Distance between location 4 and 2 is 5989.
- Distance between location 4 and 3 is 7240.

There are a total of 6 pairs of locations. Of these pairs, 4 have a distance less than 7000 between them. What is the fraction of pairs with a distance less than 7000? The final answer is $\frac{2}{3}$.

a_1.formal problem:
theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "let distances = [6300, 6609, 5944, 11535, 5989, 7240] in
               probability = (length (filter (\<lambda>x. x < 7000) distances)) / (length distances)"
shows  "probability = 2 / 3"
a_1.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The chart below gives the air distance in miles between selected world cities. If two different cities from the chart are chosen at random, what is the probability that the distance between them is less than $7000$ miles? Express your answer as a common fraction.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
& Bangkok & Cape Town & Honolulu & London \\ \hline
Bangkok & & 6300 & 6609 & 5944 \\ \hline
Cape Town & 6300 & & 11,535 & 5989 \\ \hline
Honolulu & 6609 & 11,535 & & 7240 \\ \hline
London & 5944 & 5989 & 7240 & \\ \hline
\end{tabular} The final Answer is \frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 Although there are 12 entries on the table, there are only 6 different ``pairs'' of cities. Of the 6 pairs, 4 of them are less than 7,000 miles apart, yielding a $\boxed{\frac{2}{3}}$ probability that you select a pair less than 7,000 miles apart.
 *)

theorem
fixes probability :: real
assumes h0 : "let distances = [6300, 6609, 5944, 11535, 5989, 7240] in
               probability = (length (filter (\<lambda>x. x < 7000) distances)) / (length distances)"
shows  "probability = 2 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_1.informal problem: Given the distances [6300, 6609, 5944, 11535, 5989, 7240], what is the probability that a randomly chosen distance is less than 7000? The final answer is $\frac{2}{3}$.

a_2.formal problem:
theorem
fixes bangkok_cape_town bangkok_honolulu bangkok_london cape_town_honolulu cape_town_london honolulu_london :: real
assumes h0 : "bangkok_cape_town = 6300"
and h1 : "bangkok_honolulu = 6609"
and h2 : "bangkok_london = 5944"
and h3 : "cape_town_honolulu = 11535"
and h4 : "cape_town_london = 5989"
and h5 : "honolulu_london = 7240"
shows  "card {dist. dist < 7000} / card {dist. dist \<in> {bangkok_cape_town, bangkok_honolulu, bangkok_london, cape_town_honolulu, cape_town_london, honolulu_london}} = 2 / 3"
a_2.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The chart below gives the air distance in miles between selected world cities. If two different cities from the chart are chosen at random, what is the probability that the distance between them is less than $7000$ miles? Express your answer as a common fraction.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
& Bangkok & Cape Town & Honolulu & London \\ \hline
Bangkok & & 6300 & 6609 & 5944 \\ \hline
Cape Town & 6300 & & 11,535 & 5989 \\ \hline
Honolulu & 6609 & 11,535 & & 7240 \\ \hline
London & 5944 & 5989 & 7240 & \\ \hline
\end{tabular} The final Answer is \frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 Although there are 12 entries on the table, there are only 6 different ``pairs'' of cities. Of the 6 pairs, 4 of them are less than 7,000 miles apart, yielding a $\boxed{\frac{2}{3}}$ probability that you select a pair less than 7,000 miles apart.
 *)

theorem
fixes bangkok_cape_town bangkok_honolulu bangkok_london cape_town_honolulu cape_town_london honolulu_london :: real
assumes h0 : "bangkok_cape_town = 6300"
and h1 : "bangkok_honolulu = 6609"
and h2 : "bangkok_london = 5944"
and h3 : "cape_town_honolulu = 11535"
and h4 : "cape_town_london = 5989"
and h5 : "honolulu_london = 7240"
shows  "card {dist. dist < 7000} / card {dist. dist \<in> {bangkok_cape_town, bangkok_honolulu, bangkok_london, cape_town_honolulu, cape_town_london, honolulu_london}} = 2 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_2.informal problem:
Consider the following distances between cities in miles:

1. Bangkok to Cape Town: 6,300 miles
2. Bangkok to Honolulu: 6,609 miles
3. Bangkok to London: 5,944 miles
4. Cape Town to Honolulu: 11,535 miles
5. Cape Town to London: 5,989 miles
6. Honolulu to London: 7,240 miles

What is the ratio of the number of distances less than 7,000 miles to the total number of distances? The final answer is $\frac{2}{3}$.

a_3.formal problem:
datatype City = Bangkok | CapeTown | Honolulu | London

fun distance :: "City \<Rightarrow> City \<Rightarrow> nat" where
  "distance Bangkok CapeTown = 6300" |
  "distance Bangkok Honolulu = 6609" |
  "distance Bangkok London = 5944" |
  "distance CapeTown Bangkok = 6300" |
  "distance CapeTown Honolulu = 11535" |
  "distance CapeTown London = 5989" |
  "distance Honolulu Bangkok = 6609" |
  "distance Honolulu CapeTown = 11535" |
  "distance Honolulu London = 7240" |
  "distance London Bangkok = 5944" |
  "distance London CapeTown = 5989" |
  "distance London Honolulu = 7240" |
  "distance _ _ = 0"

theorem
  fixes p :: "City \<Rightarrow> City \<Rightarrow> real"
  assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y. p x y = (if distance x y < 7000 then 1 else 0)"
shows  "sum_p (sum_p p) / 6 = 2 / 3"
a_3.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The chart below gives the air distance in miles between selected world cities. If two different cities from the chart are chosen at random, what is the probability that the distance between them is less than $7000$ miles? Express your answer as a common fraction.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
& Bangkok & Cape Town & Honolulu & London \\ \hline
Bangkok & & 6300 & 6609 & 5944 \\ \hline
Cape Town & 6300 & & 11,535 & 5989 \\ \hline
Honolulu & 6609 & 11,535 & & 7240 \\ \hline
London & 5944 & 5989 & 7240 & \\ \hline
\end{tabular} The final Answer is \frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 Although there are 12 entries on the table, there are only 6 different ``pairs'' of cities. Of the 6 pairs, 4 of them are less than 7,000 miles apart, yielding a $\boxed{\frac{2}{3}}$ probability that you select a pair less than 7,000 miles apart.
 *)

datatype City = Bangkok | CapeTown | Honolulu | London

fun distance :: "City \<Rightarrow> City \<Rightarrow> nat" where
  "distance Bangkok CapeTown = 6300" |
  "distance Bangkok Honolulu = 6609" |
  "distance Bangkok London = 5944" |
  "distance CapeTown Bangkok = 6300" |
  "distance CapeTown Honolulu = 11535" |
  "distance CapeTown London = 5989" |
  "distance Honolulu Bangkok = 6609" |
  "distance Honolulu CapeTown = 11535" |
  "distance Honolulu London = 7240" |
  "distance London Bangkok = 5944" |
  "distance London CapeTown = 5989" |
  "distance London Honolulu = 7240" |
  "distance _ _ = 0"

theorem
  fixes p :: "City \<Rightarrow> City \<Rightarrow> real"
  assumes h0 : "\<forall>x y. p x y = (if distance x y < 7000 then 1 else 0)"
shows  "sum_p (sum_p p) / 6 = 2 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_3.informal problem:
Consider the following distances (in miles) between cities:

- Bangkok to Cape Town: 6300
- Bangkok to Honolulu: 6609
- Bangkok to London: 5944
- Cape Town to Honolulu: 11535
- Cape Town to London: 5989
- Honolulu to London: 7240

Now, define a function $p(x, y)$ such that $p(x, y) = 1$ if the distance between cities $x$ and $y$ is less than 7000 miles, and $p(x, y) = 0$ otherwise. Calculate the average value of $p(x, y)$ for all possible pairs of cities. The final answer is $\frac{2}{3}$.

a_4.formal problem:
definition distance_map :: "(string * string) \<Rightarrow> int" where
"distance_map (c1, c2) = (
  if (c1 = ''Bangkok'' \<and> c2 = ''Cape Town'') \<or> (c1 = ''Cape Town'' \<and> c2 = ''Bangkok'') then 6300
  else if (c1 = ''Bangkok'' \<and> c2 = ''Honolulu'') \<or> (c1 = ''Honolulu'' \<and> c2 = ''Bangkok'') then 6609
  else if (c1 = ''Bangkok'' \<and> c2 = ''London'') \<or> (c1 = ''London'' \<and> c2 = ''Bangkok'') then 5944
  else if (c1 = ''Cape Town'' \<and> c2 = ''Honolulu'') \<or> (c1 = ''Honolulu'' \<and> c2 = ''Cape Town'') then 11535
  else if (c1 = ''Cape Town'' \<and> c2 = ''London'') \<or> (c1 = ''London'' \<and> c2 = ''Cape Town'') then 5989
  else if (c1 = ''Honolulu'' \<and> c2 = ''London'') \<or> (c1 = ''London'' \<and> c2 = ''Honolulu'') then 7240
  else 0)"

theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> (c1,c2) | c1 \<in> {''Bangkok'', ''Cape Town'', ''Honolulu'', ''London''} \<and> c2 \<in> {''Bangkok'', ''Cape Town'', ''Honolulu'', ''London''} \<and> c1 \<noteq> c2 \<and> distance_map (c1, c2) < 7000. 1) / 6"
shows  "p = 2 / 3"
a_4.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The chart below gives the air distance in miles between selected world cities. If two different cities from the chart are chosen at random, what is the probability that the distance between them is less than $7000$ miles? Express your answer as a common fraction.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
& Bangkok & Cape Town & Honolulu & London \\ \hline
Bangkok & & 6300 & 6609 & 5944 \\ \hline
Cape Town & 6300 & & 11,535 & 5989 \\ \hline
Honolulu & 6609 & 11,535 & & 7240 \\ \hline
London & 5944 & 5989 & 7240 & \\ \hline
\end{tabular} The final Answer is \frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 Although there are 12 entries on the table, there are only 6 different ``pairs'' of cities. Of the 6 pairs, 4 of them are less than 7,000 miles apart, yielding a $\boxed{\frac{2}{3}}$ probability that you select a pair less than 7,000 miles apart.
 *)

definition distance_map :: "(string * string) \<Rightarrow> int" where
"distance_map (c1, c2) = (
  if (c1 = ''Bangkok'' \<and> c2 = ''Cape Town'') \<or> (c1 = ''Cape Town'' \<and> c2 = ''Bangkok'') then 6300
  else if (c1 = ''Bangkok'' \<and> c2 = ''Honolulu'') \<or> (c1 = ''Honolulu'' \<and> c2 = ''Bangkok'') then 6609
  else if (c1 = ''Bangkok'' \<and> c2 = ''London'') \<or> (c1 = ''London'' \<and> c2 = ''Bangkok'') then 5944
  else if (c1 = ''Cape Town'' \<and> c2 = ''Honolulu'') \<or> (c1 = ''Honolulu'' \<and> c2 = ''Cape Town'') then 11535
  else if (c1 = ''Cape Town'' \<and> c2 = ''London'') \<or> (c1 = ''London'' \<and> c2 = ''Cape Town'') then 5989
  else if (c1 = ''Honolulu'' \<and> c2 = ''London'') \<or> (c1 = ''London'' \<and> c2 = ''Honolulu'') then 7240
  else 0)"

theorem
fixes p :: "real"
assumes h0 : "p = (\<Sum> (c1,c2) | c1 \<in> {''Bangkok'', ''Cape Town'', ''Honolulu'', ''London''} \<and> c2 \<in> {''Bangkok'', ''Cape Town'', ''Honolulu'', ''London''} \<and> c1 \<noteq> c2 \<and> distance_map (c1, c2) < 7000. 1) / 6"
shows  "p = 2 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_4.informal problem:
In a distance map between four cities - Bangkok, Cape Town, Honolulu, and London - the distances are as follows:

1. Bangkok to Cape Town: 6300
2. Bangkok to Honolulu: 6609
3. Bangkok to London: 5944
4. Cape Town to Honolulu: 11535
5. Cape Town to London: 5989
6. Honolulu to London: 7240

Calculate the probability that the distance between two randomly chosen cities is less than 7000. The final answer is $\frac{2}{3}$.

a_5.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distances :: "real list"
assumes h0 : "distances = [6300, 6609, 5944, 11535, 5989, 7240]"
and h1 : "count (\<lambda>x. x < 7000) distances / count (\<lambda>x. True) distances = (2::real) / 3"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>x. x < 7000) distances = (2::real) / 3"
a_5.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The chart below gives the air distance in miles between selected world cities. If two different cities from the chart are chosen at random, what is the probability that the distance between them is less than $7000$ miles? Express your answer as a common fraction.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
& Bangkok & Cape Town & Honolulu & London \\ \hline
Bangkok & & 6300 & 6609 & 5944 \\ \hline
Cape Town & 6300 & & 11,535 & 5989 \\ \hline
Honolulu & 6609 & 11,535 & & 7240 \\ \hline
London & 5944 & 5989 & 7240 & \\ \hline
\end{tabular} The final Answer is \frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 Although there are 12 entries on the table, there are only 6 different ``pairs'' of cities. Of the 6 pairs, 4 of them are less than 7,000 miles apart, yielding a $\boxed{\frac{2}{3}}$ probability that you select a pair less than 7,000 miles apart.
 *)

theorem
fixes distances :: "real list"
assumes h0 : "distances = [6300, 6609, 5944, 11535, 5989, 7240]"
and h1 : "count (\<lambda>x. x < 7000) distances / count (\<lambda>x. True) distances = (2::real) / 3"
shows  "probability (\<lambda>x. x < 7000) distances = (2::real) / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_5.informal problem: Given a list of distances $[6300, 6609, 5944, 11535, 5989, 7240]$, find the probability of a distance being less than 7000. The final answer is $\frac{2}{3}$.

a_6.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The chart below gives the air distance in miles between selected world cities. If two different cities from the chart are chosen at random, what is the probability that the distance between them is less than $7000$ miles? Express your answer as a common fraction.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
& Bangkok & Cape Town & Honolulu & London \\ \hline
Bangkok & & 6300 & 6609 & 5944 \\ \hline
Cape Town & 6300 & & 11,535 & 5989 \\ \hline
Honolulu & 6609 & 11,535 & & 7240 \\ \hline
London & 5944 & 5989 & 7240 & \\ \hline
\end{tabular} The final Answer is \frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 Although there are 12 entries on the table, there are only 6 different ``pairs'' of cities. Of the 6 pairs, 4 of them are less than 7,000 miles apart, yielding a $\boxed{\frac{2}{3}}$ probability that you select a pair less than 7,000 miles apart.
 *)

theorem
fixes p :: real
assumes h0 : "p = (\<lambda>x. if x < 7000 then 1 else 0)"
and h1 : "h0 6300 = 1"
and h2 : "h0 6609 = 1"
and h3 : "h0 5944 = 1"
and h4 : "h0 11535 = 0"
and h5 : "h0 5989 = 1"
and h6 : "h0 7240 = 0"
shows  "sum h0 {6300, 6609, 5944, 11535, 5989, 7240} / 6 = 2 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_6.informal problem: Consider a function $p(x)$ such that $p(x) = 1$ if $x < 7000$ and $p(x) = 0$ otherwise. Given that $p(6300) = 1$, $p(6609) = 1$, $p(5944) = 1$, $p(11535) = 0$, $p(5989) = 1$, and $p(7240) = 0$, find the average value of the function $p(x)$ for the given set of input values $\{6300, 6609, 5944, 11535, 5989, 7240\}$. The final answer is $\frac{2}{3}$.

a_7.formal problem:
theorem
fixes bangkok_to_capetown bangkok_to_honolulu bangkok_to_london
capetown_to_honolulu capetown_to_london honolulu_to_london :: real
assumes h0 : "bangkok_to_capetown = 6300"
and h1 : "bangkok_to_honolulu = 6609"
and h2 : "bangkok_to_london = 5944"
and h3 : "capetown_to_honolulu = 11535"
and h4 : "capetown_to_london = 5989"
and h5 : "honolulu_to_london = 7240"
shows  "fraction_of_distances_less_than_7000 = 2 / 3"
a_7.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The chart below gives the air distance in miles between selected world cities. If two different cities from the chart are chosen at random, what is the probability that the distance between them is less than $7000$ miles? Express your answer as a common fraction.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}

& Bangkok & Cape Town & Honolulu & London \\ \hline
Bangkok & & 6300 & 6609 & 5944 \\ \hline
Cape Town & 6300 & & 11,535 & 5989 \\ \hline
Honolulu & 6609 & 11,535 & & 7240 \\ \hline
London & 5944 & 5989 & 7240 & \\ \hline
\end{tabular} The final Answer is \frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 Although there are 12 entries on the table, there are only 6 different ``pairs'' of cities. Of the 6 pairs, 4 of them are less than 7,000 miles apart, yielding a $\boxed{\frac{2}{3}}$ probability that you select a pair less than 7,000 miles apart.
 *)

theorem
fixes bangkok_to_capetown bangkok_to_honolulu bangkok_to_london
capetown_to_honolulu capetown_to_london honolulu_to_london :: real
assumes h0 : "bangkok_to_capetown = 6300"

and h3 : "capetown_to_honolulu = 11535"

and h5 : "honolulu_to_london = 7240"
shows  "fraction_of_distances_less_than_7000 = 2 / 3"

  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_7.informal problem:
Given the following distances between cities:

1. Bangkok to Cape Town: 6300 miles
2. Bangkok to Honolulu: 6609 miles
3. Bangkok to London: 5944 miles
4. Cape Town to Honolulu: 11535 miles
5. Cape Town to London: 5989 miles
6. Honolulu to London: 7240 miles

What fraction of these distances are less than 7000 miles? The final answer is $\frac{2}{3}$.

a_8.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distances :: "(string * string) \<Rightarrow> real option"
assumes h0 : "distances ('Bangkok', 'Cape Town') = Some 6300"
and h1 : "distances ('Bangkok', 'Honolulu') = Some 6609"
and h2 : "distances ('Bangkok', 'London') = Some 5944"
and h3 : "distances ('Cape Town', 'Honolulu') = Some 11535"
and h4 : "distances ('Cape Town', 'London') = Some 5989"
and h5 : "distances ('Honolulu', 'London') = Some 7240"
and h6 : "distances (x, y) = None \<longleftrightarrow> x = y"
shows  "CARD {(x, y). distances (x, y) \<noteq> None \<and> the (distances (x, y)) < 7000} / CARD {(x, y). distances (x, y) \<noteq> None} = 2 / 3"
a_8.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The chart below gives the air distance in miles between selected world cities. If two different cities from the chart are chosen at random, what is the probability that the distance between them is less than $7000$ miles? Express your answer as a common fraction.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
& Bangkok & Cape Town & Honolulu & London \\ \hline
Bangkok & & 6300 & 6609 & 5944 \\ \hline
Cape Town & 6300 & & 11,535 & 5989 \\ \hline
Honolulu & 6609 & 11,535 & & 7240 \\ \hline
London & 5944 & 5989 & 7240 & \\ \hline
\end{tabular} The final Answer is \frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 Although there are 12 entries on the table, there are only 6 different ``pairs'' of cities. Of the 6 pairs, 4 of them are less than 7,000 miles apart, yielding a $\boxed{\frac{2}{3}}$ probability that you select a pair less than 7,000 miles apart.
 *)

theorem
fixes distances :: "(string * string) \<Rightarrow> real option"
assumes h0 : "distances ('Bangkok', 'Cape Town') = Some 6300"
and h1 : "distances ('Bangkok', 'Honolulu') = Some 6609"
and h2 : "distances ('Bangkok', 'London') = Some 5944"
and h3 : "distances ('Cape Town', 'Honolulu') = Some 11535"
and h4 : "distances ('Cape Town', 'London') = Some 5989"
and h5 : "distances ('Honolulu', 'London') = Some 7240"
and h6 : "distances (x, y) = None \<longleftrightarrow> x = y"
shows  "CARD {(x, y). distances (x, y) \<noteq> None \<and> the (distances (x, y)) < 7000} / CARD {(x, y). distances (x, y) \<noteq> None} = 2 / 3"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_8.informal problem:
In a set of distances between cities, we have the following information:
- The distance between Bangkok and Cape Town is 6300 units.
- The distance between Bangkok and Honolulu is 6609 units.
- The distance between Bangkok and London is 5944 units.
- The distance between Cape Town and Honolulu is 11535 units.
- The distance between Cape Town and London is 5989 units.
- The distance between Honolulu and London is 7240 units.
- No distance is given for a city to itself.

What is the fraction of city pairs with distances less than 7000 units to the total number of city pairs with distances? The final answer is $\frac{2}{3}$.

a_9.formal problem:
theorem
fixes distances :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "distances = {6300, 6609, 5944, 11535, 5989, 7240}"
and h1 : "card distances = 6"
and h2 : "card {x \<in> distances. x < 7000} = 4"
shows  "ereal ((\<Sum>x\<in>{x \<in> distances. x < 7000}. indicator distances x) / (\<Sum>x\<in>distances. indicator distances x)) = (2 / 3)"
a_9.formal solution:
(* ### Problem
 The chart below gives the air distance in miles between selected world cities. If two different cities from the chart are chosen at random, what is the probability that the distance between them is less than $7000$ miles? Express your answer as a common fraction.

\begin{tabular}{|c|c|c|c|c|}
\hline
& Bangkok & Cape Town & Honolulu & London \\ \hline
Bangkok & & 6300 & 6609 & 5944 \\ \hline
Cape Town & 6300 & & 11,535 & 5989 \\ \hline
Honolulu & 6609 & 11,535 & & 7240 \\ \hline
London & 5944 & 5989 & 7240 & \\ \hline
\end{tabular} The final Answer is \frac{2}{3}
 ### Proof
 Although there are 12 entries on the table, there are only 6 different ``pairs'' of cities. Of the 6 pairs, 4 of them are less than 7,000 miles apart, yielding a $\boxed{\frac{2}{3}}$ probability that you select a pair less than 7,000 miles apart.
 *)

theorem
fixes distances :: "real set"
assumes h0 : "distances = {6300, 6609, 5944, 11535, 5989, 7240}"
and h1 : "card distances = 6"
and h2 : "card {x \<in> distances. x < 7000} = 4"
shows  "ereal ((\<Sum>x\<in>{x \<in> distances. x < 7000}. indicator distances x) / (\<Sum>x\<in>distances. indicator distances x)) = (2 / 3)"
 proof- 
  show ?thesis sledgehammer
a_9.informal problem: Out of six recorded distances, 6300, 6609, 5944, 11535, 5989, and 7240, what is the ratio of the number of distances less than 7000 to the total number of distances? The final answer is $\frac{2}{3}$.
